page.name: Culminating Activity
page.intro: Now that you have completed all sessions in Project-Based Science Instruction for Career Preparation, you will have an opportunity to reinforce what you have learned. Having selected a PBL topic that is relevant to your students, uses science as a context, and connects to environmental science and energy conservation, apply what you’ve learned in this course by beginning to plan your own PBL initiative. Proceed to the Culminating Activity to begin planning your program. You will continue to build on your initial ideas over the coming days and weeks.
page.content:
Activity Instructions

Begin planning your program using this your Self-Reflection Handout to capture your ideas. The Culminating Activity questions in the handout will help you generate ideas for integrating all that you have learned in this course into your class. These questions integrate three important factors:

The Eight Characteristics of Effective PBL

  1. Significant Content
  2. Skills for Success
  3. Real Inquiry
  4. Open-ended Driving Question
  5. Compelling Event
  6. Student Voice
  7. Revision and Reflection
  8. Public Audience

2. Characteristics of Adult Learners

Adult learners:

  • are internally motivated and self-directed;
  • bring life experiences and knowledge to learning experiences;
  • are goal-oriented;
  • are relevancy oriented;
  • are practical; and
  • like to be respected

3.      The Eight Scientific Practices

  1. Asking questions and defining problems
  2. Developing and using models
  3. Planning and carrying out investigations
  4. Analyzing and interpreting data
  5. Using mathematics and computational thinking
  6. Constructing explanations and defining solutions
  7. Engaging in argument from evidence
  8. Obtaining, evaluating, and communicating information

In your Self-Reflection Handout, answer these questions below to capture a few new ideas you could implement in your classroom. Save these ideas for later use, and add to it as you develop more ideas and find out more about your learners and their interests and current knowledge and skills. 

Guiding Questions:

  1. What significant content related to the STEM area will you teach?
  2. How will you build on students’ current knowledge?
  3. How will you create opportunities for both presenting the information in varying ways and allowing students to express themselves in varying ways?
  4. How will you integrate (a) critical thinking, (b) problem-solving, (c) collaboration, and (d) various forms of communication?
  5. How will you use inquiry as part of the process of learning and creating something new?
  6. What types of open-ended driving question(s) will your learners strive to answer?
  7. What compelling event will you use to activate students’ need to know and engage them in the content?
  8. How will you allow for student voice and choice?
  9. How will you include the processes of revision and reflection?
  10. What public audience will see the outcomes of the student project?
  11. Which scientific practices will you integrate and how?
  12. How will your project benefit the community?
  13. Are there any collaborative teaching opportunities you might investigate?

Once finished, please proceed to the course conclusion.
